prior_works.title: A Simple Adaptive Procedure Leading to Correlated Equilibrium
prior_works.role: Foundational link between no-regret learning and setwise equilibrium (empirical) outcomes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This classic result that no-external-regret learning drives empirical play to (coarse) correlated equilibria is the benchmark the paper departs from when shifting focus from time-averages to the day-to-day strategy trajectory and its setwise rationality properties.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Approximations and Differential Inclusions
prior_works.authors: M. Benaïm, J. Hofbauer, S. Sorin
prior_works.role: Methodological backbone for linking discrete-time learning to continuous-time dynamics and invariant/attractor sets
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s equivalence between dynamic and strategic stability relies on viewing regularized no-regret algorithms as asymptotic pseudo-trajectories of differential inclusions, a perspective enabled by Benaïm–Hofbauer–Sorin’s framework for attractors and internally chain transitive sets.

prior_works.title: Stable Games and Their Dynamics
prior_works.role: Structural results on stability and attraction under broad classes of payoff-monotonic/regularized dynamics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The finding that only strict Nash equilibria can be asymptotically stable under standard learning dynamics motivates the paper’s setwise approach and informs the dynamical side of the equivalence proved for regularized learning.

prior_works.title: Learning in Games via Reinforcement and Regularization
prior_works.role: Immediate precursor formalizing continuous-time limits of FTRL/mirror descent and Bregman Lyapunov structure in games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present paper builds directly on the regularized learning dynamics and Lyapunov/Bregman geometry developed here to characterize attractors and link them to strategic (setwise) stability notions.

prior_works.title: On the Strategic Stability of Equilibria
prior_works.role: Foundational concept of setwise strategic stability in game theory
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper adapts the Kohlberg–Mertens notion of strategic stability from equilibrium refinements to the repeated-play/learning context and proves that dynamically stable sets under regularized learning coincide with strategically stable sets.

prior_works.title: Strategy Subsets Closed Under Rational Behavior
prior_works.role: Setwise rationality framework (CURB sets) capturing unilateral deviation closure
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s criterion that any unilateral deviation from the set is costly echoes CURB-style setwise rationality, and this work provides conceptual grounding for the setwise targets that the authors equate with dynamical attractors.

prior_works.title: Quantal Response Equilibria for Normal Form Games
prior_works.authors: R. D. McKelvey, T. R. Palfrey
prior_works.role: Regularization-based equilibrium refinement via entropic penalties/noisy best responses
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By interpreting regularization as a deviation cost (e.g., entropic penalties underlying logit responses), this work underpins the paper’s strategic notion under regularized learning and helps connect pathwise dynamic stability to setwise strategic stability.

synthesis_narrative: The paper addresses a long-standing gap between empirical convergence guarantees of no-regret learning and the actual evolution of players’ strategies. Hart and Mas-Colell established that no-external-regret learning drives time-averaged play to (coarse) correlated equilibrium, but this says little about day-to-day strategies. To study pathwise behavior, the authors rely on the stochastic-approximation and differential-inclusion toolkit of Benaïm–Hofbauer–Sorin, which allows discrete regularized algorithms (e.g., FTRL/mirror descent) to be analyzed via continuous-time dynamics and their invariant/attractor sets. On the dynamical side, Hofbauer–Sandholm showed that under broad payoff-monotonic/regularized dynamics, only strict Nash equilibria can be asymptotically stable—highlighting the limitations of pointwise equilibrium predictions and motivating a move to setwise notions. Building on the continuous-time regularized learning framework and Bregman Lyapunov structure developed by Mertikopoulos–Sandholm, the paper characterizes attractors of regularized learning dynamics. On the strategic side, it draws on the setwise perspective of Kohlberg–Mertens’ strategic stability and the CURB-set rationale of Basu–Weibull, where sets are judged by their robustness to unilateral deviations. Finally, the entropic lens of McKelvey–Palfrey’s quantal response connects regularization to a quantifiable cost of deviating, aligning dynamic stability under regularized learning with a stringent setwise strategic criterion. Together, these strands enable the central result: dynamically stable sets of regularized learning trajectories coincide with strategically stable sets, thereby unifying dynamic and strategic stability in repeated play.
